reviewText: I have played the first and second game of Force Unleashed and i have to say that even though i got the SECOND game for five pounds and the FIRST for 15 punds i still believe that the second is worth far less than the first. It gives you nowhere near as much customisation or options when it comes to compat (which is very repetetive anyway) combos consist of mashing atack button and randomly adding force somwhere along the way (or lightning if you prefer). enemies are piled up on top of eachother soo badly that i found myself using the repulse over and over and over again untill a certain sequence finished. options with upgrades are also very limited (if you can call these options) you get 3 levels of each power (sabre, force, lightning etc) and choose between each one when you can upgrade them. They got rid of option of seperate colour crystals and ability crystal (life leach, fire, electric etc) for your sword, that means you get no red life leach or green lightning blades like you always wanted. sound track is nothing special cant complain but i found myself at no point in game just standing and listinening to a great tune.\nIMPORTANT PART: if you want a game that you can play for a day then by all means leave this game in the dark room and lock it with a three foor iron door for this game has an overall paly time of an average COD game, this game finished at a point where you would with all honesty expect anotehr two hours of game play. sucks that does. at the same time the ONLY choice you get in game is at THE VERY END whic hgives you with all honesty absolutelly no satisfaction at all when you are shown credits 30 seconds after you made your choice.   Graphcal glitches were also present whihc often ruined the mood of hte game.\nSUMMING UP: If you are a hardcore fan of SWTFU 1 the nby all means buy this if you just enjoyed it but you are not a hardass star wars fan do NOT buy this unless it drops to       £3.50     at its highest. it is not worth more than this.

reviewText:
I knew the game was bad, but it exceeded my expectations.

The port quality is as bad if not worse as the first game (which was already about as low as you can go), but even ignoring that, the game feels unfished in general.

There's an egregious amount of copy/paste level design with only 3 unique environments in total, and even then the game finds ways to have you backtrack though the same level on occasion.  On top of this there's a general lack of polish. Glitchy animations, ugly UI design, poor sound balance, an incredibly poorly executed and ill advised boss fight in the middle of the game, the list goes on.

The game feels like it was hastily cobbled together in 10 months, not 2 years. I knew all of this going in and hoped to be surprised by setting my expectations very low, but nope, it's just bad.  I'll finish it (I'm less than hour from the end anyway - Steam playtime is not accurate because I was offline for a bit), but out the traditional single player storyline games I've completed in the last 5 years, this is easily the worst.

reviewText:
This was a severely disappointing game.

It started off so good, which made it all the worse.  You start and instantly realize that the gameplay has gotten an improvement and that you feel just as powerful as your end-game Starkiller from TFU1.  Unfortunately, this is the only good part of the game- and you soon realize that it's terrible that you start so powerful.  You never get any stronger, or you never feel like you do.  This game lasted 4 hours at the VERY most and included a whopping 3 separate locations.  No, I refuse to count Dagobah as a location because you walk around for 45 seconds (I swear to God, I'm not even being sarcastic this time) and then watch a boring cutscene.  Then you leave.

The trailers promised a more personal, darker, grittier story line, but in reality it's a few hours of Starkiller running around murdering storm troopers and whining while Kota nags at him over the communicator.

Oh, and the pathetic 3.5-4 hours this game wastes includes an approximately 45 minute long boss fight.  It's not even difficult.  Literally the hardest part of this game was not slitting my own wrists while jacking off Darth Vader and watching his health bar move down slower than a dead snail in frozen molasses for the better part of an hour

Yeah, I know I'm being harsh. And of course it's always gonna be great fun to throw storm troopers out of the skybox over and over. But this game feels more rushed than deciding to finish wanking when you're already late for class.  And it's even more of a disappointment when compared to its predecessor.

Oh, also on the second boss battle, the boss didn't load.  No, I don't mean the level loaded funky- the boss itself didn't show up in the level.  So congrats on another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC port, Aspyr.  Good to know you're always looking out for a third your consumers.

reviewText:
Force Unleashed II fixes all the problems I had with the first game. The gameplay is far more fluid, the controls are simple and easy to remember, the force powers feel useful, there are enough enemies to keep the game interesting, and not too many to overcomplicate things. The menu, while still an obvious console port, works far better, with fast access to your force powers, and a simple menu to change the color of your lightsabers. One noticable change to the game's formula is that now you have two lightsabers instead of one. Also, you'll notice slowdowns whenever you land successive hits on enemies similar to how the God of War series works which I really like as it allows you to more easily plan your next move. Quick time events are unfortutely still very much present. All of the big enemy types that you fight throughout the game have an optional quick time finisher move that got boring to watch so fast, I tried to avoid pressing the quicktime activation button and just finished off the enemy by slashing it instead. One nice addition is the ability to use the force to see where you needed to go next. The first game had a problem with instructing the player on what they were supposed to do next. I also liked the ability to use mind tricks on weak enemies so they would do things like kill themselves or attack their allies.

Now here are the problems with this game. I have never in my life played a shorter game. 4 hours. That's right... 4. There are literally only 3 levels in the game: Kamino, some Cloud City like place, and a spaceship interior. The pacing feels way off, as if I was missing the first 3 levels. After the initial tutorial level, you go to this Cloud City place and fight through room upon room of increasingly difficult waves of enemies until you reach a huge colliseum where you're faced with a gigantic boss. This boss goes on FOREVER. So long, I was afraid I was already facing the end of the game. But no, this is just some overly drawn out filler that takes up a majority of the game. I'm not sure why the developers thought it important to draw this out as it isn't necessarily a fun boss that let's you use your skills to their full potential.

Another major problem is the story. It's not nearly as good as the first one. You barely interact with any of the good characters established in the first game, and your charater's motives are purely to save the damsel in distress this time which just does not feel as powerful as the motive of the first game's character. The storyline overall just feels rather uninspired and doesn't seem to add anything to the overall arch of the Star Wars universe. The cool thing about the first one was that it helped to link the prequel movies and the original trilogy together. Force Unleashed II does no such thing and feels like that awkward straight to DVD movie that nobody ever watches unless they buy it by accident.

The graphics look incredible, especially for a game that's already a couple years old. Very nice lighting, nice soft edges, and some smooth framerates. The cutscenes are also looking fantastic, almost movie quality.

The sound is a big improvement, though the music is still a bit hit/miss. The voice acting of most characters is decent, but not nearly as good as the first game. The main character's voice acting is horrendous this time around, with really awkward pubescent screams when he gets angry that just give you that awkward embarassed feeling. I just want Darth Vader to be like ..whoa.. calm down you big baby."

All-in-all

reviewText:
I somewhat enjoyed the first game, but this sequel was a mess. The endings don't make sense and the story was overall un-interesting.

The enemies were boring and all the cutscene finish moves were exactly the same. One of the things that made the original game decent is the lighsaber duels with jedi and sith, as well as the variety of ways to kill an enemy. This game lacked all of that.

There was virtually no content to the game; roughly 6 hours of play-time to finish and every level looked the same. On some planets, I could turn a corner and be in a room that looks exactly like the last room.

What was crippling is that there wasn't really anything new after the first game. This felt like the graphics were freshened up a bit and a story was added as an afterthought to get people to buy this as a new game.

This game did exactly one thing that I really liked, and that was a boss battle that happened pretty early in the game. I found that fight to be a fight worthy of the Star Wars franchise, and it is probably the only part of the game that sticks out in my mind. However, the story material for that boss battle is extremely borrowed and I have seen those same concepts in other video games and movies, which is only part of what limits that single fight from salvaging this game.

Overall, I don't play a lot of video games, and I especially don't play a lot of bad video games, so take that into account when I say that this is one of the worst games I've ever played.

reviewText:
This was a severely disappointing game.

It started off so good, which made it all the worse.  You start and instantly realize that the gameplay has gotten an improvement and that you feel just as powerful as your end-game Starkiller from TFU1.  Unfortunately, this is the only good part of the game- and you soon realize that it's terrible that you start so powerful.  You never get any stronger, or you never feel like you do.  This game lasted 4 hours at the VERY most and included a whopping 3 separate locations.  No, I refuse to count Dagobah as a location because you walk around for 45 seconds (I swear to God, I'm not even being sarcastic this time) and then watch a boring cutscene.  Then you leave.

The trailers promised a more personal, darker, grittier story line, but in reality it's a few hours of Starkiller running around murdering storm troopers and whining while Kota nags at him over the communicator.

Oh, and the pathetic 3.5-4 hours this game wastes includes an approximately 45 minute long boss fight.  It's not even difficult.  Literally the hardest part of this game was not slitting my own wrists while jacking off Darth Vader and watching his health bar move down slower than a dead snail in frozen molasses for the better part of an hour

Yeah, I know I'm being harsh. And of course it's always gonna be great fun to throw storm troopers out of the skybox over and over. But this game feels more rushed than deciding to finish wanking when you're already late for class.  And it's even more of a disappointment when compared to its predecessor.

Oh, also on the second boss battle, the boss didn't load.  No, I don't mean the level loaded funky- the boss itself didn't show up in the level.  So congrats on another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC port, Aspyr.  Good to know you're always looking out for a third your consumers.

reviewText: How I feel about The Force Unleashed II"? Well...it's more of a "meh" situation. It retains the core concept of being overpowered with the force and now you can wield two lightsabers! Sounds fun and it is fun. On the graphics side of things it has improved quite alot - facial animations and character movement have been made to feel more natural. On the gameplay side it is all there - quick and fast button combinations result in making a badass jedi/sith action that makes your jaw drop. But that is pretty much it. The story is ridiculously convoluted - the whole prequel cloning idea brought in the original trilogy mythos. The story feels unfinished and sometimes forced (no pun intended). Grind your way towards becoming overpowered and while advancing the "plot" of the story
date: face a God Of War style boss battle. Press the right button prompts and you are done.\n\nThe techinical and mechanical aspects of the game have been improved
recommended: but there is no narrative to drive the player to finishing the game. In the end I would only recommend the game if you could get it on sale
hoursPlayed: otherwise buy the original with tons of more content and better story."

reviewText:
I liked the first Force Unleashed. I played in on 360 and thought it was fine. I got this on a sale a long time ago and never got around to playing it. Until yesterday.

And then I beat it.

I am not good at video games. But even I thought this game was ridiculously easy. And short. Which is not helped by the game's lack of difficulty. Seriously, I was done in about 4 hours on medium difficutly. And I took my time to try and find some of those dumb holocrons and mess around with the force powers. I have been told the dark ending has some additional stuff to do. But I didn't pick that ending. Given how the game closes with the light side option, there is still more stuff to do anyway. But that's not in this game.

When you play the game, it basically becomes: saber attack with lightning or use lightning. The combat was not interesting. The enemy types were very predictable and were not well placed. The boss fights were not any better. I really only remember two: the giant monster and the last one. I'm not sure if I missed bosses or just misunderstood what parts of the game counted as boss fights. But those fights were just boring.

The story is also pathetically weak. Even by old EU Star Wars standards. To be fair, it's really hard to make a story be relatable when your main character is so stupidly overpowered. I get that the super powers are the point. They enable the fun" of the game. But it's really not fun. There is nothing to do worth doing. Even if we assume the game was fun to play
date: that's no excuse to go this lazy with the plot. And to end on that cliffhanger? Why? Just finish the story. Who thought this was enough content? I guess I shouldn't be too upset
recommended: I didn't like what they did up to that point.\n\ntl;dr - The game is short
voteText: forgettable
helpfulPercent: and just bad. If you are looking to waste money and are a Star Wars fan/somewhat liked the first game
votesHelpful: just buy something else. Seriously. Don't buy this game."

reviewText:
Short version:  8 out of 10 if you're a fan, 7 out of 10 if you're not, and maybe 6 out of 10 if you don't like action games.

Why? [SPOILERS AHEAD]

First of all, it's STAR WARS, so that has that going for it.  Even with the whole Legends"/"Canon" thing
date: the story is enjoyable and engaging.  The final sequence before facing Vader in the end is incredibly well done:\n\n- cramped camera (normally a bad thing
recommended: but here it really highlights the stress and pressure that Starkiller feels
hoursPlayed: an outstanding cinematic technique)\n- the lighting (stark
voteText: clinical white in places
helpfulPercent: but it still manages to look dark and insidious; the blood-red lights at each of the abberant clone-tanks really accent the sinister operations there)\n- the Force energy (Starkiller's surroundings crumple and disintegrate
votesHelpful:
which provides a VERY visual metaphor at how he's struggling to keep from losing his mind.)


While you need to have played the first one to really understand all the nuances of this game
votesTotal:
the cinematics and dialogue fill in the blanks enough for brand new players to grasp the events and goings-on.

The ability to customize not one but TWO lightsabers not only provides gameplay bonuses but can also serve as roleplaying tools if you so desire.  You start with red crystals but can find others as you play...

RED: no bonus
BLUE: lightsaber strikes replenish Force meter
GREEN: more health pickups from defeated enemies
YELLOW: lightsaber strikes deal additonal lightning damage
CHARTREUSE: lightsaber attacks deal additonal corrosive damage
ORANGE: lightsaber strikes deal additional fire damage
PURPLE: take less damage from attacks
PINK: Force Fury meter recharges faster from attacking
LIGHT BLUE: Force powers use less energy
LIGHT GREEN: health regenerates faster
LIGHT ORANGE: more experience points for collateral/environmental damage
BLACK: lightsaber attacks have a chance to disintegrate enemies
WHITE: more experience points for defeating enemies
(I may have missed one or two
votesFunny: there's a lot of them)\n\nForce powers make a comeback
commentsCount: and are more streamlined.  Plus a new one
column17:
where you can make enemies flee the battle (often by jumping of a ledge to their demise) or even fight for you.

The voice acting is well done.  You hear the unbridled power when Starkiller taps into Force Fury and the despair when Vader outmaneuvers him.  Rahm Kota speaks with authority on the starship Salvation and speaks out of weariness when he knows that Starkiller is the only one who can turn the tide.

~~~~~

The reason for the multiple scores is relatively simple.  Most people know that the game was rushed due to the Lucasfilm/Disney merger; and with this game being the second in a trilogy
column18: the fact that the trilogy has been shelved indefinitely... that can put a downer on somebody.\n\nIf you are a STAR WARS fan who enjoyed the films
column21: then you'll enjoy this game.\nPut it on your wishlist
column22: watch for a sale if you're worried
column23: there's a decent amount of replayability and the difficulty can be whatever you make of it.\n\nIf you want something that you can just button-mash through
column24: then play on easy.  You'll still be able to enjoy the story.\nIf you want to feel like every battle is like when Luke faces Vader in the second Death Star
column25: then play on the hardest difficulty setting.\n\nUnfortunately
column26: and as much as it pains me to say it... if you're not a fan of action games or combo systems you may not have as much fun with this.  If you're not a STAR WARS fan
column27: then why are you even reading this?\n\nIt's not a BAD game by any means
column29:
it's clear that there was more to be had but real-life events forced their hand.

~~~~~

SYNOPSIS:  At once engaging
column31:
and haunting; the continuation of Starkiller's journey is made even more poignant by the fact that it is *not* canon.  You see the formation of a Rebellion that now never was against the machinations of an Empire that now never were.

It's a bit like the work of an artist.  Once they're gone what they've made is now priceless.

Even though Starkiller is no longer "real"
column33: and that's the soul of this game."

reviewText:
I am a huge star wars fan and I loved the first Force Unleashed.
PROS
-The game has some of the most beautiful weather cycles and graphics shading I have ever seen.
-The fighting animations are awesome and the new lightsabre physics (cutting arms of stormtroopers) make a nice new addition.
-The stormtroopers are so weak... but it's fun to muck around with them.

BADS
-Similarly to most reviews, I have to say the campaign game time is horrendous. I have finished the game 2 times, and my steam time says 6 hours.
-The gameplay is incredibly repetitive (like the first one), however, since the story is nowhere near as engaging as the first one, the gameplay is even worse as you feel there is no inscentive to see the outcome of the level.
-As I said, the story is completely irrelevant to the star wars universe. As a true-fan, no matter what I love every star wars game (especially Jedi Knight series), but this one didn't do it for me.
-There is no variation in enemies... ever!

Overall 5/10. Not recommended unless you can pick this game up for under 10 bucks.
This is a game where the graphics are incredible, but the story and gameplay drown beneath it.

reviewText:

First I really like Star Wars though beside the videogames and a few books about Obi wan prior to the Phantom Menace I never really got into the whole Expanded universe. most important thing for me, the lightsaber battles (Jedi Knight; Jedi Academy still has the best actual lightsaber battles in my opinion) it managed to have some great moments just living on this premise that your character is overpowered" in terms of his Forcepowers. reviewText:
Didn't think it would be worse than the first game, but I was wrong.

The game is ridiculously short, it took me a total of 4 hours to beat the campaign, and I was not speeding through it (I find it funny that my playtime includes watching the entirety of the credits). The amount of bugs in this game is also insane, even in game cinematics have very obvious bugs. Stormtroopers heads shaking around, Darth Vader walking through the ground, etc. When you see a pre-rendered cinematic having ridiculous bugs, just turn off your pc. There is no vertical sync option and the screen is always tearing so much so that its strange when there isn't a tear. Story is pointless and tacked on, nothing that happens is important, honestly can't even think of anything to say about it, but you will get a few laughs out how awkward it can be. The gameplay isn't even as good or tight as the first (which wasn't good or tight at all), the lightsaber pausing everytime you hit an enemy for a second drove me insane.

The only positive thing I can say about this game is that if you are a Star Wars fanatic like myself you will get a bit of enjoyment out of this. The music of John Williams is never disappointing, and a lightsaber always is fun.

This game is nowhere near $20 value as there is story based DLC for other games that are of more quality and longer than The Force Unleashed II. I honestly feel bad for anyone that paid $60 for it. It's pretty clear that the developer signed a contract saying they needed to make a sequel and had no idea what to do. There are plenty of fantastic Star Wars games that you should spend your time with such as the Jedi Knight or Knights Of The Old Republic series. Even if you have already played those games you will enjoy playing them again for four hours more than you will enjoy beating The Force Unleashed II's campaign.

Still not convinced? Okay lets try this **waves hand** you will not buy this game.

Edit: Just found out that this does not include the DLC for the game, making it even less worth your time & money. :)

reviewText:
where the first TFU was based entirely around it's engine and tech to the detriment of it's gameplay, TFU2 is completely soulless and bland and dosen't even have gimmicks to save it from mediocrity. the tech is better and it looks nice at times, yes, but there is simply no reason for this game to exist and nothing it does justify's the purpose. it's a pointless, meandering exercise that feels like sinking into a cold bowl of porridge.

also the pc port is *busted* unless you force VSync in the control panel (on geforce cards at least, tested on a 970) and the framerate is locked at 30 until you install an unoffical patch. even then, i often had problems with music and sound randomly cutting out for minutes at a time only for it to come back out of sync with the game. it's not as bad as the TFU1 pc port which was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ insult, however.

seriously, avoid this. it's totally pointless.

reviewText:
As a big Star Wars fan and after being impressed with the first installment of this game I decided to move on to the sequel. I was impressed with the beginning of this game. What seemed like a solid story, fluid gameplay and beutiful graphics, I thought I was looking forward to a good game. But in the end I was disappointed.

I have completed this game in 3 hours, which for its price is ridiculous (I bought this as part of the star wars collection). It was so short. It may as well have been DLC for the first game. Even then you would expect a strong story, which it also failed to deliver. We were left with a repeat of the end of Episode 3 movie. Turns to dark side to save the women he loves but she still dies. Or the other ending where evrything is O.K. but considering what happens in the dark side endig does'nt make an appearence in the light side ending makes no sense.

This game has litrally about 4 levels (5 if you include the fill in the dots mission on Dagobah). The levle themselves never offered much. Do this force power to pass through this part. Now just to make sure you know it do it again." Then you will never do this again throughout the game.

So with all this
date: you would expect the game to at least give us a strong ending. But sadly no. We are left with a sub par boss fight with Darth Vader with very repetitive sections that just ruin the emotion of the fight.\n\nSo overll
recommended: I would not recommend buying this game at full price. Maybe if it were on sale and you are an adamnet star wars fan you may enjoy it. Some of the gameplay mechanics are amzing and very fun to play with. But at the end I was left with a sour tate in my mouth that has led me to not reccomend this game."

reviewText:
I got this with a bundle and if that hadn't been the case, I don't think I'd ever have gotten this, I went in with incredibly low expectations from what I had already heard.

I'll start off by saying the positives

- The game looks very good, especially the reflections, the character models are pretty high quality too.
- It sounds good as well (John Williams score always sounds good).
- It's always fun to fling enemies off of ledges or use the mind trick to make them kill themselves.

Now on to the negatives.

- The boss fights make Deus Ex Human Revolution's original boss fights look like masterpieces.  Incredibly repetitive to the point where I just lowered the difficulty to easy in the fight at Cato Nemoidia because of how dull and long it was.  Darth Vader was probably one of the worst boss fights I've ever played in a game, it just goes on forever and is incredibly repetitive.
- Only three areas Kamino, Cata Nemoidia (which is the longest and best level despite the terrible boss fight), and a rebel ship.  I don't count Dagobah because you don't do anything there.  Basically there are only 4-5 levels total compared to the like 10 of the first game.
- Too short, it's only about half the length of the first game, I beat it in about 5 hours.
- Incredibly repetitive, towards the end I just played even the levels on easy due to how dull they were.
- Mostly uninteresting story, especially compared to the first game.
- Lack of anything really new over the first game, besides Jedi Mindtrick and wielding two lightsabers, there isn't much new.
- More quciktime events than 1.
- Inferior to the first game in every way (except graphics obviously).

reviewText:
This game is worth at best 1£/hour. Seeing as it clocks in at 4 hours in a fairly avarage run, I'd say avoid it like the plague.

Usability:
This is also because it has numerous issues running properly on my win 7. To actually get it to start you need to change the compability settings of you .exe, an .exe which you must first download online if you actually want to play your figther game at 60fps instead of 30. Add to that the long, unskippable start up movies (which you can fix with another download).  Of course you also have some random crashes ( i counted 4) during playtime, and a few glitches while plaing. All in all it's not a very good port. Though i will say it actually does present graphical options, unlike it's predesessor.

Combat:
The gameplay is very much the same as one. You have you're similar attacks, lightsaber throwing, litghtning firing and normal saber combat basically. Where it changes is in the speed of combat. Your dash ability from 1 has a shorter cooldown, you wield 2 lightsabers instead of one, which basically means you hit faster, but you're comboing abilities are if anything increased. Unlike the 1st installment, you have little ability to change hit quickly, so you mostly end up doing a quick few slahes on normal enemies, and spam the normal 4 hit combo on more tough ones.

There are two new installments. Those are mindtricks, the ability to turn a weak enemy to your side, and rage. Mindtricks replace the sheild from 1, but offers little useability to make up for this. Since you dispose of enemies so quickly, and the effect last such a short time, it barely sees any use. Rage on the other hand works as you would expect. you kill enemies, build up ragem, and get a damage boast for a short amount of time on use. All in all it is an allright mechanic, if a bit underused.

Tha min issue with the combat lies in it's overreliance of quick time events. Any enemy stronger than your common lightsaber uer or stormtrooper is finished using the same qte, with minor variations in buttons. This means since you have the same animations and enemies throughout the game, you end up repeating it for atleast 50 times over the course of playing. Add to that the stronger focus in bossfights. where earilier the main combat was indeed swordplay and force use, with qte's being used as finishers, here almost the entirety of the bossfights are qtes.

Upgrades:
As in 1, you have your lightsaber upgrades. These are colloected as holocrons, which are fairly easy to find as you progress through the game. They are cosmetic and gameplay effects rolled into one, where you can pick one crystal for ech saber, having effectssuch as drain health,

You also have your powerupgrades as in 1. In 2 these are instead streamlined" or perhaphaps simplu dumbed down
date: into one page. Previously you could upgrade your powers
recommended: your combos and your player strenghts (hp
hoursPlayed: energy etc9 with different points earned by lvling up and completing challanges. Here you get all your points based on enemy death (as in bulletstrom). Your upgrade all your swordplay (damage

helpfulPercent: and the rest upgrades your indivudual forcepowers. The problem with this way is you loose the sense of progression of 1. Since you have all the useful combos from a fully upgraded jedi from 1
votesHelpful: you dont actually receive any interesting new combos with upgrades. This leads to all upgrades essentialy being damage buffs
votesTotal: something which isnt very exciting for a quick
votesFunny:
combo based combat.

Aesthetics:
Immidiatley you can see they put a lot of effort into making this a beautiful game. The scale of the eniroments
commentsCount: and graphical fidelity are much better than 1
column16: and are enjoyable throughout the game. The only gripe i have is that they removed the enemy healthbars

making fairly difficult to know the damage required to actually bring down enemies.

Story:
This game picks up a year or so after 1

column19: and becomes obsessed with finding the (very) brief love interest of 1. That's it. That's the story. You find Kota from 1

and fight Vader. Game over. This in a game where half the time (atleast) is spent in qte's and cutscenes. Needless to say it doesn't offer enough.

Conclusion:
It feels like this game was horribly rushed. The potential lies to have the game stretch atleast another 4 hours

reviewText:
If you’re looking for a great game, please stop here. This game isn’t great, it’s not even good. Mediocre would describe it best. Star Wars the Force Unleashed 2 is rather bland. Here is a breakdown of the game:
•	Graphics: The game looks nice. Nice crisp visuals help make the game look good.  The rain on Kamino looks amazing, and the destructible environments make the visuals pretty. 7/10
•	Framrate: Playing on PC is not recommended as the game isn’t optimized well. You’ll run into problems similar to the predecessor. Low framerate. The game tries, but ultimately fails to stay at 30FPS, with frequent drops to as low as 11FPS. As I was playing on the PC, not being able to make the game run at 60FPS, as I do most other games, with the constant drops make this a painful sore on my eyes. 2/10
•	Gameplay: This is much like driving your first car. It feels amazing at first. You feel like you have all the power in the universe, but then you take a second to realize how boring driving really is. The game tries to throw a few curves your way, but by now you know how your car runs, and these curves really do nothing but slow you down a little. You fight the same enemies over and over again, with the only variation being the combination of the enemies. You can take everything down with your lightsaber. Very little thought is needed to mow down the enemies. You can spice it up using some combinations, but the X-X-X-X combination is really all you need. A few enemies are hard to hit, and you just have to throw a little lightning at them, but that’s all you need to do. The bosses are not much better. All you have to do is learn a simple pattern, and lather, rinse, repeat. They don’t change how they’re acting, and the get predictable really fast. 4/10
•	Level design: The levels don’t really resonate well. They are long, and filled with the same waves of enemies over and over again. The platforming bits mix it up a little bit, and in my opinion, the best levels are the ones where you are falling. You have to dodge out of the way of incoming objects, or you can blast them aside with a force push. But that’s it. Platforming becomes a chore in this game, and sometimes it’s just rather frustrating. 3/10
•	Story: The story jumps around, and all you ever seem to do is teleport to wherever the plot says you have to go with nothing really tying it all together. The jump between level one and two is rather Jarring. You escape from the cloning facility on Kamino when Vader is about to kill you, and then all of sudden you are trying to track down your old master from the last game. No explanation. The romantic side of the story is lacking, and feels half ♥♥♥♥♥. 2/10
•	Length: The game is short. Painfully so. You can beat this game in a matter of hours with no difficulty. You will get to the final level and feel like the game is half over at best. You can beat this game in about 4 hours, if you include the cutscenes. If you ignore the cutscenes, it ranges between 2 and 3 hours at most. The most replayability you get is from playing with a different costume, such as a Storm trooper or Boba Fett. 3/10
All in all, this game feels like it shouldn’t exist. It adds nothing new to the lore, which as of this writing is non canon, but regardless. The game is short, doesn’t feel great, the story is lacking, but it looks nice. Don’t play this game, it will leave you with an empty feeling inside. Nothing is really of note. If you really want to play this game, then I suggest you get it heavily marked down, or like I did and get it in a bundle where you only paid a few dollars for. My final scoring of the game is a 3.5/10.

reviewText: Force Unleashed series to me is the second worst thing to happen to the star wars franchise since Jar Jar binks. I find it reminiscent to a play station 1 platformer, with sort of flashier graphics. If you're a brain dead drooling zombie that gets a woody from seeing flashing lights, then yea I suppose this game is for you. That or you can spent $5 bucks paying someone to jingle a shiny set of keys infront of you. For what ever reason, you're a god in the game, not a jedi, not a sith...you're unstoppable. reviewText:
The last time I played the first Force Unleashed game was some years ago, and I vividly remember it as being the Jedi/Sith power trip that Star Wars games were missing until then. It had fun and easy to use force mechanics, the best I'd seen, with a passable story and decent brawler gameplay to boot. Outside of a few frustrating segments and glitches, it was an amazing experience, which held my attention for a good 20+ hours.

With that in mind, I was excited for the sequel. Unfortunately, The Force Unleashed II pales in comparison to its predecessor. Its 4-6 hour length is probably its greatest weakness, and this game certainly has weaknesses. Perhaps by itself it's not that bad of a game, although I can't help but compare it to the first game, an adventure which saw you flying around the galaxy, from jungles to lava planets to imperial ships, fighting various rancors, robots, Jedi and Sith. It was amazing! This game, however, barely innovates at all on what the previous title had to offer; the combat system remains largely unchanged, the story this time around is decidedly boring, and the enemy and location variety seem to be worse than before. Strangely enough, even the menu graphics stand out as outdated and clunky.

Bottom line, play the first Force Unleashed instead. The only thing this game does better is graphics.

reviewText:
The first Force Unleashed was by no means a perfect game. On just about every count, Force Unleashed II is worse.

While this game continues to let you play a god-like Jedi who tosses aside armies with a swat of his hand, that's about all it really gets right.

Controls: Stiffer and less natural than before, with limited mobility on your character. You can fly through the air, but can't walk faster than a hurried trot. It's been a while since I've played the first one, but in this one my movement felt hamstrung.

Enemies: Just as in the first game, enemies eventually cope with your god-like powers by being magically immune to some of them (though this is usually less annoying than it is the first time around). I wonder where Vader's armies of secret Force-immune warriors and missile-toting robots went by the beginning of A New Hope.

Boss fights tend to have incredibly simple patterns, and yet drag on endlessly.

Level Design: There are a few interesting set-pieces in this extremely linear game, but too often the design slows you down with endless and very dull jumping and locking mechanism puzzles" that really do nothing but delay your progress with pointless tedium.

Overall art direction is OK
date: with a fair amount of work put into some levels and not so much into others.\n\nStory: Anyone who played the first game knows that the Force Unleashed story is totally ridiculous but serviceable
recommended: given that they're just trying to write some kind of plot around the fun gameplay gimmick of being an ultra-powerful Jedi. Despite what a cheesy tie-in it was
hoursPlayed: it felt epic in its own way.\n\nThis time around
voteText: though
helpfulPercent: the writers completely phoned it in. Nothing is explained if you haven't played the first game
votesHelpful: and makes little sense even if you did. The plot is extremely lazy--your character doesn't even really talk for the first two levels or so
votesTotal: and there's a lot of pointless cameos. Yoda shows up
votesFunny: says two lines to the protagonist
commentsCount: and then disappears before either character asks the other's name.\n\nIn terms of storytelling depth
column16: it feels like a half-baked DLC add-on for the first game at best. That may be a generous assessment. The game is noticeably short
column17: even compared to the fairly short first game.\n\nMusic: About the same as before
column18: with an OST consisting of exactly one musical sting for your character. All other music is recycled John Williams score
column19: even if it wouldn't be terribly appropriate for the given moment in the game.\n\nCharacter Customization: There's still a paper-thin leveling system (your choices here don't really matter). Your lightsaber provides you different bonus stats based on the color
column20: but the advantages from color to color are not terribly significant. There doesn't appear to be much in the way of other cosmetic options.\n\nTechnical Aspects: I could forgive this game's shortcomings if it weren't for the problem that it's a classic example of a bad console port. Most of the graphics settings are completely locked--including the framerate and refresh rate--and it appears that it's impossible to change them. The options menu is clearly blown up from a lower resolution--it looks terrible on 1080. Many users report severe problems on their systems

column23: and I've had a better experience than many

I.. I don't know what to say about this. It's a fun hack n' slash game, and like any other hack n' slash game, it's become too repetitive and boring in no time.

and the one thing that bothering me so much and I'll just spit it out here. THE WHOLE ♥♥♥♥ING STORY IS SO BAD, it makes me want to cry knowing that Star Wars franchise having such a strong story even with the cartoon and comic one.
The whole story is about you, the main character a.k.a Starkiller, saving the Juno from Boba Fett that kidnapping her.
THAT'S IT, IT'S ONLY ABOUT THAT. you just chasing Boba Fett all over the place until you meet Darth Vader and (not even) finish him.

the second boss, well, easy as ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: This dissapointing sequel to the original Force Unleashed once again follows Starkiller(or is it Starkiller's clone?) as he rampages across the galaxy and inadvertantly starts the rebellion that made star wars good in the first place. Through visits to a series of forgettable, repetitive locations and a boring cliched story that makes no sense you will once again slash, burn and electrocute anything that moves. Rule of thumb, if it has appeared in star wars in the last twenty years then you can kill it. A forgettable tale of revenge with the end game being a showdown with Darth Vader in which you literally beat the truth out of him. This game is shallow on content, its about five hours long, and it is oh so glitchy. Do not pay more than five dollars for this game, it is not as good as the original by any stretch of the imagination. The only good parts of this game were the voice acting and motion capture which as always were top notch, and the physics engine which lets you grab tie fighters out of the air with the force. And the ending, light or dark, won't answer your questions.

reviewText:
I've not recommended this game due to the completion time and the lack of replay-ability.

If you're looking at this game, you've probably played the first one. If not, play the first one. Be warned that it only took me 5 hours to complete the first one and 4 hours to complete this one.

You carry on your journey as the Sith Apprentice. It's so similar to the first game that they may aswell have merged the two together, at least it would have reached a decent completion time.

You're overpowered as hell, pump up the points in force lightning and you're good to go. The thing didn't die? Hit it with your lightsabres, it will die long before you do.

The boss battles in this one were a little more difficult, however that isn't saying much. It's good for a 'filler' game, worth picking up if it's on sale and you have nothing better to play.


All in all, I'd give this game a Jawa out of 10.

reviewText:
I cannot stress enough how poorly Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II is coded and optimized for PC play.  It is abhorrently, horrendously ported from its console iteration, to the point of true unplayability.  This is not a game.  This is a semi-interactive slideshow if its FPS count is anything to go by.  I'll be clear:

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR PC.

I can't vouch for its console iterations, as I haven't played them, but save your money, PC gamers.  This was the first Steam purchase after which I felt truly, criminally cheated.  There is no reasonable way to make use of what I bought, and that's not right.  For record, yes, my computer meets and exceeds the minimum specs for installing and playing this game by a longshot, so it's not a user issue.  It's a coding issue, and a damned unforgivable one.

reviewText:
Gonna be honest, the fact that you can mind trick a stormtrooper into killing himself is good enough for me.
...*coughs* oh we're live?

Starkiller: These men will kill you *mindtricks stormtrooper*
Stormtrooper: NOT IF I KILL THEM FIRST!

this is a very unique game, and while it's basically just a second part to the same game as it's prequel, its a great game.
Did I feel ripped off for buying it? no.
I got it in humble bundle for like £12 - would I pay the full wack for it normally? no.

for sure, this is one of those games that you play to START OFF in RPGS
A few points to mention;

♥ Overpowered AF character (if you die that much, just quit, uninstall and never play another game, this is THE easiest game i've ever played, with the exception of maybe the first one)
♥ small range of weaponry customisations, keep it simple.
♥ compression of buttons. everything can be hit without struggling.
♥ Finally it's keeping the characters simple, we already know most of them, Vader from Episode 4-6, Starkiller from the first game - not too confusing for the little padawans.

This is what I would consider a starter game. now if you're looking for a challenge after this and you're feeling brave, go fly a hellicopter in ARMA3 - the controls? well you're gonna need to keep your hands.. pretty central to the keyboard.

the ultimate test of course, did this game make me dress like a jedi while making coffee in the kitchen? Yes. it did.

reviewText:
For the first time I must say: IGNORE THE METACRITICS. This game excels in both combat, storyline, dialogues, voice acting, graphics and playability. It has verything: combats, puzzles, real-time action, minigames, sequences, and it even tailors the story as you play based on the choices you make.

*SPOILER ALERT* When I first started this game and saw the first level was Kamino I knew it was off to a good start, and that I made a wonderful deal buying this. Absolutely gorgeous. I'm a big Kamino fan, and I really hope I get to visit it. *SPOILER FINISHED*

But seriously; this game is even better than the first one, which I also recommend. And it looks better than most modern games even though it's relatively old. So, if you read any critics that destroy this game, at least give this game the benefit of the doubt and get it when it's on sale. You may have a sweet surprise around the corner.

reviewText:
I'm 4 hours into the game and I'm already on the last level. Let me repeat that: Game story is about 6 hours tops. And you pay 20$ for this.  You pay 20$ to have maybe 6 hours of fun (more about that latter.) Ask yourself if this game is really worth that much. Because I don't think so.

As for gameplay it is quite solid. Except chase scenes, QTEs and minibooses. And there is a lot of chase scenes, QTEs and minibooses. And then there are booses that you have to defeat with QTEs. During chases scene. They have a great combat engine and they throw it out for QTE. Masters of design.....

From technical standpoint game is ok. Except they gave x360 code to some interns who demanded lowes pay and told them to do a PC port so it hangs like tapestry. Quality of that port is an insult to injury.

And the injury is that PC won't recieve the Endor DLC. This is all I can say about it while staing civil.

If you ever wondered why Lucasgames had to fall. Games like this are the reason.

5/10. Buy if cost less than a 5$ and you really liked first game.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Score: 6/10
Overview
You are back at Darth Vaders side training for future missions as the clone of Starkiller. Memories keep flooding back to you from Starkillers past leading Vader to consider you a flawed clone. You escape so that Vader doesn't kill you and begin your journey to find out who you are.

Positive
The combat feels better than the orignal if you ask me. Sure its a bit of a buttom mashup, but honestly who cares when it's fun. The levels aren't as big and less resources were used, but with a more streamlined design comes better playability. The graphics have been increased since the original as well, but that may also be because the levels are smaller. The boss fights in this game are fewer and less challenging, but they feel like boss fights. The boss fights are much more God of War. The PC port is actually playable.

Negative
The game is short. The smaller levels and lack of resources make some zones feel copy and pasted. The story is even more bland then the original and the ending makes you glad you didn't take much stake in it. The game did completely freeze causing me to have to restart twice.

Conclusion
This is a better PC port and the way the levels are designed to be played is much smoother then the original. It seems way to obvious that it wasn't developed as long though because the levels are repetitious and for a game that is only about 5 hours that is saying something.

Value
Considering it is a bad port of an ok game I value it at $4.

reviewText:
First off to start off this review, I had Star Wars The Force Unleashed 1 on my Playstation 2 and loved the game. Star Wars The Force Unleashed 2 I'm kind of indifferent about it. Hear are my pros and cons.

Pros
The Force Abilities
Good story line
Alot of cosmetic custimization
Challenges give good replay value
Supports Console Controls (This worked perfectly)

Cons
Beat the whole game in 6-7 hours on my first ever playthrough
Level Design isn't the greatest. Alot of the areas look almost identical to other areas on a mission
Less combos then SWTFU1
The lightsaber combo just doesn't feel as smooth as it did in the first game
Quick time events are horrible

I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who has not played the first SWTFU game. SWTFU1 is far superior to this game. I would highley recommend any Star Wars fan to try out the first game. This game I would only recommend buying if you can get it for under 5$ on a sale. My overall final impressions on the game is it felt like a beta so I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price. The game is enjoyable but not as fun as the first one.

reviewText:
A sub par sequel. The first game was quite innovative, I remember awaiting it eagarly years ago..... You got to fight rancors, go into a sarlaac, fight on the first deathstar,  fight other jedi, do all of it on a variety of planets, and bring a whole Star Destroyer crashing down using just the force.

Here you get two lightsabers................. and I wouldn't even call that an improvement.... but thats the closest thing you get to an improvement... Here you get to fight on a grand total of 2 planets....... and the only really remarkable thing you do is fight a giant creature created just for this game..... and you end up doing it in way that seems to directly plagiarize Lord of the Rings..... unlike the first game, you aren't left at all with the impression that you get to unleash the force, instead you're just an average force user...... The enemy force users... get to use better force powers than you do. At the end I was left thinking, thats it? thats the whole game?!!!!!"

Overall the only thing I am happy about with this game.... is that I didn't pay anything close to full price due to the humble bundle (bundle cost $12)... This was pretty much the worst game in the bundle...... Remarkable considering the oldest game on the bundle had almost a whole 15 years on this game.  If you're going to buy this game by itself.... don't.... just stick with the original force unleashed."

reviewText:
If the best level in an action game is the one where there is no fighting at all,just walking and cinematics...it says a lot about the game, doesn't it.

The Force Unleashed II is a lazy cash grab sequel that shouldn't have been made. Apart from a few moments, and all of them are non-combat related, it is a bland,boring and short game.

The story is...well not much of a story. It somehow feels empty, no structure, no twists, no anything. The only potential twist they could have done is more of a hint that leaves it up to you to think about it, but it's not one of those mindblowing things you wrap your head around for days. In this case, it is up to a minute. And then you're back to cursing Lucas for deciding to make this game.

The combat is the same as in the previous game, but somehow you are even more overpowered, and with the regenerating health and the ridiculously overpowered force lightning, you will just breeze through the game. Oh wait, you won't. Because it is filled with too many QTEs. Almost everything is a QTE. Every other door requires you to mash a button in order to open it. And the prompts are scattered to the sides of the screen so you have to look everywhere just to see them, and it doesn't help that they are small and easily blend with the surrondings.

The level and boss design are just lazy and atrocius. In the first game, levels did happen on same planets, but those were outdoor areas and they did bother to make them look interesting visually. Here there is a lot of backtracking through monotonous corridors and hallways, just wishing for the game to end. Bosses come down to silly QTEs followed by sillier button mashing with no patterns or anything. The final level+boss are especially frustrating, with the former consisting of a single needlessly long and generic platforming section...copied twice more. And that one section consists of a single platform copied ten times or so. And the boss is just a bunch of waves of enemies followed by button mashing...followed by a long QTE which ends with you having to mash the Q button for some 10s or so. And the game is ridiculously short even with the backtracking and level copy-pasting, and can be easily beaten in about 2-3 hours tops.

If I would have to choose anything good about the game...it would be the Dagobah level, mentioned at the beginning of this review.No fighting at all, just great ambient,atmosphere and cutscenes. Two more nice moments, both without fighting...and that would be it. Voice actors did the best they could, and did a pretty good job if I might say, but they can't do anything for the bland writing for an even blander story.

This is a game that definitely shouldn't have been made, and you shouldn't waste your time and money on it. If you are still interested in the story, might as well go to YT and watch all the cinematics (and maybe levels)...it might even be more enjoyable than playing the game itself.

reviewText:
Game: Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II
Format: PC
Released: 0ctober 2010
With the recent advent of Humble Bundles or at least to me they are newish I decided to buy to star wars bundle. In said bundle I received overall a total of 12 star wars games, I won't bore you with the list but that is a lot of star wars.  The game I want to draw attention to here is Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II.

Now  personally I loved the first game other than the levels on Felucia it was a genuinely stellar game. It made you feel powerful, like a real force user out for revenge. The second one? Not so much. It's good and I enjoyed my time with it but my biggest issue is time. I completed the game quit out looked and steam and there it was. FOUR hours of game play from start to finish. Granted I was running through it on medium difficulty but even so should a sequel to a game that had a solid 8-10 story with a ♥♥♥♥ tonne of DLC released after the fact last FOUR ♥♥♥♥ing hours? No is the answer to that question. I'll save that rant for later though let's talk about the good first shall we?

Graphics

It was a beautiful game when it first released back in October 2010 and it really does still stand up 4 years later. Weather effects, clothing moving in high winds, the motion capture is genuinely stellar it really shines through. Environments are fantastic and true to the movies, there are really very few games that get as visually close to delivering a star wars experience like Force Unleashed II. The flip side to this is artifacting everywhere all the time. graphical glitches were many and if this were a longer game maybe it would count as less but after FOUR hours there are just far too many graphic glitches. Another thing that ties into that is absolutely no V-syncing options at all and it's constantly stuck at 30FPS no matter the hardware configuration.

Game Play/Mechanics

This is another place where I feel the game before was a better example of how to do things.  It had a better level system,  It had the better skill upgrades In the prequel you gain experience, level up, earn talent spheres, and the spend them on abilities. combos, and skills. in the sequel every time you break something or someone you gain force points which you then spend on the 6 skills open to you. This is literally it. you gain minor other bonuses from different Light Saber crystals but it's so insignificant its barely even worth mentioning. The fighting is much the same but with a severe lack of combos (of which there are only about 20 as opposed to the amount from game number one) really limits the flashy combat and pulls you away from feeling like you are a stupidly powerful Jedi/Sith. No real puzzle elements or alternate paths and that really doesn't help it's case of FOUR hours.

Sound

This will be a real short one. It sounds like Star Wars. biggest point to note here is like the prequel Mr James Earl Jones returns as the voice of Darth Vader. Voice acting is actually very well don across the board but then again you only ever hear about 5 characters actually speak. whodathunkit?

Replayability

NOPE. FOUR hours. FOUR hours. On a harder difficulty I might've gone a whopping 5 hours. some challenges await after completing the game and what DLC was released when pulled from sale for whatever reason. Once this game is finished there is NO reason to EVER come back to it.

Story

You play as the clone of Starkiller for game numero uno on a quest for revenge and to save the one he loves. awww isn't that cute? isn't it also the most generic thing ever? I won't rant too much here I did enjoy it even for its generic seen it before storyline the voice acting really helped me trundle through the story. Much like the first game(noticing a theme yet?) you will be required to fight Darth Vader. this is the highlight of any of the bosses but I felt even that may have dragged on a bit too long.

Okay rant time. Lucas Arts all you had to do was make the first game again make it look prettier and everyone would have been so happy with the end product but no, like every other developer you decide that you should change one of the fundamentally greatest things from the first game. The progression for Starkiller. you took what made that game great and just ♥♥♥♥ all over it with number 2(see what I did there?) I really wish that you had just copy pasted for number 2 and considering that  because of Disney we won't get number 3 there are so many things you left unanswered. is he Starkiller prime? is he just a clone like all the rest? If he is a clone why can he use the force? There is a real simple solution to all of this. DONT MAKE IT FOUR ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! another 4-6 hours and you could have told the rest of star killers story and fans would have been happy but now all I have is an empty pit of unanswered questions and disappointment for series that could have been so much more.

Positives

•	Graphically beautiful
•	Stellar voice work
•	James Earl Jones

Negatives

•	Story was bland and been there done that
•	graphical glitches
•	FOUR hours
•	No replayability what so ever
•	FOUR hours

I wish I could rate this higher but its only worth a 5 out of 10 IF this is your first outing with SW:TFUII then it will be fine and fun but please go back and play the first one it's so much better.

I would not recommend this game to others.  Like some other people I bought the Humble Bundle Star Wars for February 2015.  However this was the worst game I have ever came across.

One start up the SWTFU2.exe would crash so I had to go to the folder teamApps\common\Star Wars The Force Unleashed 2 and changed the Compatibility to see if it would start.

When it did start the audio during the cinematics of it.  Also it would crash/freeze completely making me end the process via Task Manager.  Video also get out of sync and stops.

After trying to start the game and it crashing after again and again you can't even play the game as it doesn't allow you to skip the Cinematic.

It also has the fun issue of killing your network connection.  Steam, Skype etc all die when playing this game.  Not suitable.  With Task Manager opened you can see that the CPU usage is maxed out at 100%.

5/10. Buy if cost less than a 5$ and you really liked first game.

reviewText: Quite possibly the shortest game I've ever played (I clocked in just about five hours). Force Unleashed II is very obviously a mere afterthought to its predecessor, with a campaign that without the long stretches of repetitive combat would make a fine piece of DLC, but is fairly laughable as a standalone game. The plot feels cut down to the bone marrow, with major plot points and character beats hand-waved in a way that hints ever so meekly at the epicness that could have been. Starkiller's bond to Vader could make for an explosive, compelling relationship, but we only ever see Vader briefly in the beginning and for the final boss confrontation at the end. We're to understand Starkiller is haunted by his former master throughout, but the dark lord's presence is all but forgotten after the initial escape from the cloning labs on Kamino. In general, the sometimes comically unhinged Starkiller is a completely unrelatable protagonist. Apparently his love for Captain Juno Eclipse, with whom he shared a shy kiss before plunging into the depths of the Death Star at the end of the original, has grown to such obsessive proportions that he turns his back on the rebellion he helped kickstart. Juno herself is even more of a non-entity than previously. She barely gets any lines and exist only as a lazy plot device to keep Starkiller moving along.\n\nHaving said all that, it's a beautiful looking game with a couple of truly spectacular set pieces. I don't regret playing it, but I would strongly suggest holding off until it's to be had for a fiver.

reviewText: Although I recommend this game, I do so cautiously. I purchased this game as part of a bundle and played it immediately after Force Unleased I. The game looks significantly better, and is much less buggy than its predecessor. Hurling baddies across the galaxy is a lot of fun and the force powers work much better in this game than they did before. That being said, there are still a lot of really strange bugs that can hamper gameplay at various times. I had to restart one level because the auto-sequence wouldn't initiate due to one of the troopers getting stuck in a wall. I couldn't eliminate him and the sequence couldn't play out.\nThere are a ton of fun moments in this game. You'll fight giant monsters, use the force in powerful ways and say 'wow' more than once. That being said, the game is highly repetitive. Unlike the first game, there is little variety. For example, in the Force Unleashed, you can trigger a QTE to eliminate certain foes. There was more than one animation for these baddies because I'm sure the developers wanted things to feel fresh. Unfortunately, that variety was not carried over to this game. You fight the same guys over and over again and QTE them to the same animations over and over. It becomes boring and lackluster. The final boss" battle was extremely repetitive and I simply tuned out. I'm sure if I had had a laser pointer
date: I could have had a cat jump on the strike button multiple times for twenty minutes and had won. I would have given the game an 7.5 out of 10. After the final fight
recommended: I give the game a 6. I couldn't believe how boring it was. Strike

reviewText:
I'm 4 hours into the game and I'm already on the last level. Let me repeat that: Game story is about 6 hours tops. And you pay 20$ for this.  You pay 20$ to have maybe 6 hours of fun (more about that latter.) Ask yourself if this game is really worth that much. Because I don't think so.

As for gameplay it is quite solid. Except chase scenes, QTEs and minibooses. And there is a lot of chase scenes, QTEs and minibooses. And then there are booses that you have to defeat with QTEs. During chases scene. They have a great combat engine and they throw it out for QTE. Masters of design.....

From technical standpoint game is ok. Except they gave x360 code to some interns who demanded lowes pay and told them to do a PC port so it hangs like tapestry. Quality of that port is an insult to injury.

And the injury is that PC won't recieve the Endor DLC. This is all I can say about it while staing civil.

If you ever wondered why Lucasgames had to fall. Games like this are the reason.

5/10. Buy if cost less than a 5$ and you really liked first game.

reviewText:
This is a really great game if you can get past the bugs. I have a ton to say about this 2nd installment as I did the first.

pro's
-Same as the first one outstanding story and acting. More star wars? totally win!
Robot chicken says it best here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jkhOXw9bk6Y
-movement and controls are sweet!
-graphics are awesome. Living in the star wars world with high res, priceless
-AI is not half bad, but nothing to write home about. It's not broken and that's good enough for me
-only paid $5.00 for it on a trundle bundle (whatever it's called) instead of $50.00 when it came out
-Lucas Studios might be Disney but whomever dev'd this redeemed themselves with this one despite the crashes. This game is fun just like Knights of the Old republic only modern. Well done!

con's
-many game or even computer crashing problems.

How to fix the major problems? Not sure try this:
Many of the suggestions found by clicking support" link when you have this game higlighted in your steam library will take you to a page of a bunch of comments on this game. For me it was a combination of things and I tried so many things before it started working I have no idea what it was.

Originally when I started up this game it made my computer completely lock up to an endless black screen and all I could do was cold reboot my computer. Not good for your system at all! For having to do that several times I am still pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

find the SWTF2.exe (whatever the name is) in it's directory
date:
right click > properties > compatability:
-compat with windows xp
-desktop compat
-admin

Also I ran it in resolution native to the game which was really low rez for the initial intro. That allowed me to get into the game and not crash my computer. After letting the game save during game-play a few times I notched up the graphics to 1920 x 1080 and it finally started working. Not sure why it took a wind up but it did.
Hope that helps someone. I was pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and many people who tried using this game never got it working. Good luck to you. Just keep trying stuff until it works."

reviewText:
Having recentially picked these games up on a humble bundle i as looking forward to getting into them. after completig TFU 1, a game i thought was really fun and had a great story and decent upgredes system and over all even though i thought it was pretty short i liked it and was was looking to any impovements they may have made from the first one.
The second game prettty much takes up where the last left off whithout gettiing to the story you start a good deal more powerful than you did in the first game.
Improvements/positives; *Great graphics-better than the last one
*Dual lightsabres are just cooler
*levels are nicer in some cases with a lot more desuction
* combat seems a little more fluid, camera is better.
cons                                 *Story is very poor by comparison to the first, its still not that bad but its pretty weak mostly and elements that could have made it much more engaging were kind of ignored after they looked like they would be pivitol. ( the whole clone thing)

* Although i really like the titght combat, you can really swing some really cool combos together it can get a little repetetitive as the game goes on( last fight is pathetic in terms of wash rince repeat and the fact that the story doesnt make me even care that im fighting him, as we never really see the love interest thing develop much(even in the first game) , i found myself not caring what happend to her.
* Kind of a big one that it seems a lot of people have experienced is the stuttering cutscenes and random crashes, i delt with the cutscenesas there are not that many but it can get bad , and the ridiculous slow down if you wear robes that flow ( this is apparently the reason)

OVERALL; I liked the game but i was glad it was short as there was not much there to keep you interested in the campaign. Great graphics great gameplay ok story, god damn kota is annoying in ths one! I d reccomment getting it on sale for 5 bucks if you can and playing it with a 360 pad, at least i found this a lot easier. Nice addition to the first game but to be honest seems like it was put together in a hurry, doesnt do anything different but thats not necessarilly a bad thing .   6.5/10

reviewText:
Game: Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II
Format: PC
Released: 0ctober 2010
With the recent advent of Humble Bundles or at least to me they are newish I decided to buy to star wars bundle. In said bundle I received overall a total of 12 star wars games, I won't bore you with the list but that is a lot of star wars.  The game I want to draw attention to here is Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II.

Now  personally I loved the first game other than the levels on Felucia it was a genuinely stellar game. It made you feel powerful, like a real force user out for revenge. The second one? Not so much. It's good and I enjoyed my time with it but my biggest issue is time. I completed the game quit out looked and steam and there it was. FOUR hours of game play from start to finish. Granted I was running through it on medium difficulty but even so should a sequel to a game that had a solid 8-10 story with a ♥♥♥♥ tonne of DLC released after the fact last FOUR ♥♥♥♥ing hours? No is the answer to that question. I'll save that rant for later though let's talk about the good first shall we?

Graphics

It was a beautiful game when it first released back in October 2010 and it really does still stand up 4 years later. Weather effects, clothing moving in high winds, the motion capture is genuinely stellar it really shines through. Environments are fantastic and true to the movies, there are really very few games that get as visually close to delivering a star wars experience like Force Unleashed II. The flip side to this is artifacting everywhere all the time. graphical glitches were many and if this were a longer game maybe it would count as less but after FOUR hours there are just far too many graphic glitches. Another thing that ties into that is absolutely no V-syncing options at all and it's constantly stuck at 30FPS no matter the hardware configuration.

Game Play/Mechanics

This is another place where I feel the game before was a better example of how to do things.  It had a better level system,  It had the better skill upgrades In the prequel you gain experience, level up, earn talent spheres, and the spend them on abilities. combos, and skills. in the sequel every time you break something or someone you gain force points which you then spend on the 6 skills open to you. This is literally it. you gain minor other bonuses from different Light Saber crystals but it's so insignificant its barely even worth mentioning. The fighting is much the same but with a severe lack of combos (of which there are only about 20 as opposed to the amount from game number one) really limits the flashy combat and pulls you away from feeling like you are a stupidly powerful Jedi/Sith. No real puzzle elements or alternate paths and that really doesn't help it's case of FOUR hours.

Sound

This will be a real short one. It sounds like Star Wars. biggest point to note here is like the prequel Mr James Earl Jones returns as the voice of Darth Vader. Voice acting is actually very well don across the board but then again you only ever hear about 5 characters actually speak. whodathunkit?

Replayability

NOPE. FOUR hours. FOUR hours. On a harder difficulty I might've gone a whopping 5 hours. some challenges await after completing the game and what DLC was released when pulled from sale for whatever reason. Once this game is finished there is NO reason to EVER come back to it.

Story

You play as the clone of Starkiller for game numero uno on a quest for revenge and to save the one he loves. awww isn't that cute? isn't it also the most generic thing ever? I won't rant too much here I did enjoy it even for its generic seen it before storyline the voice acting really helped me trundle through the story. Much like the first game(noticing a theme yet?) you will be required to fight Darth Vader. this is the highlight of any of the bosses but I felt even that may have dragged on a bit too long.

Okay rant time. Lucas Arts all you had to do was make the first game again make it look prettier and everyone would have been so happy with the end product but no, like every other developer you decide that you should change one of the fundamentally greatest things from the first game. The progression for Starkiller. you took what made that game great and just ♥♥♥♥ all over it with number 2(see what I did there?) I really wish that you had just copy pasted for number 2 and considering that  because of Disney we won't get number 3 there are so many things you left unanswered. is he Starkiller prime? is he just a clone like all the rest? If he is a clone why can he use the force? There is a real simple solution to all of this. DONT MAKE IT FOUR ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS! another 4-6 hours and you could have told the rest of star killers story and fans would have been happy but now all I have is an empty pit of unanswered questions and disappointment for series that could have been so much more.

Positives

•	Graphically beautiful
•	Stellar voice work
•	James Earl Jones

Negatives

•	Story was bland and been there done that
•	graphical glitches
•	FOUR hours
•	No replayability what so ever
•	FOUR hours

I wish I could rate this higher but its only worth a 5 out of 10 IF this is your first outing with SW:TFUII then it will be fine and fun but please go back and play the first one it's so much better.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I would not recommend this game to others.  Like some other people I bought the Humble Bundle Star Wars for February 2015.  However this was the worst game I have ever came across.

One start up the SWTFU2.exe would crash so I had to go to the folder teamApps\common\Star Wars The Force Unleashed 2 and changed the Compatibility to see if it would start.

When it did start the audio during the cinematics of it.  Also it would crash/freeze completely making me end the process via Task Manager.  Video also get out of sync and stops.

After trying to start the game and it crashing after again and again you can't even play the game as it doesn't allow you to skip the Cinematic.

It also has the fun issue of killing your network connection.  Steam, Skype etc all die when playing this game.  Not suitable.  With Task Manager opened you can see that the CPU usage is maxed out at 100%.

reviewText:
TL;DR An underwhelming sequel that is very linear and repetitive.

I had got this game in a bundle, and having already played the first Force Unleashed, I was expecting an improved experience, as I had already taken a liking to the first.

The combat mechanics are okay, but once the game tells you about Force lightning grenades, there is very little incentive to even use the lightsaber, save for the OP grappling move, which can then lend  itself to doing the former (see: Acolytes and other Jedi).

I completed all of the challenges, did not grind, and beat it on Hard in ~5 hours. Would not recommend to those seeking time for their dime.

reviewText:
First off to start off this review, I had Star Wars The Force Unleashed 1 on my Playstation 2 and loved the game. Star Wars The Force Unleashed 2 I'm kind of indifferent about it. Hear are my pros and cons.

Pros
The Force Abilities
Good story line
Alot of cosmetic custimization
Challenges give good replay value
Supports Console Controls (This worked perfectly)

Cons
Beat the whole game in 6-7 hours on my first ever playthrough
Level Design isn't the greatest. Alot of the areas look almost identical to other areas on a mission
Less combos then SWTFU1
The lightsaber combo just doesn't feel as smooth as it did in the first game
Quick time events are horrible

I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who has not played the first SWTFU game. SWTFU1 is far superior to this game. I would highley recommend any Star Wars fan to try out the first game. This game I would only recommend buying if you can get it for under 5$ on a sale. My overall final impressions on the game is it felt like a beta so I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price. The game is enjoyable but not as fun as the first one.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First off, you can decapitate storm troopers with your light sabers so I'd recommend it just for that.

I thoroughly enjoyed Force Unleashed 2 however I would only recommend at under a $10 price point. The game is very short (about 5 hours) and only has three different level types, Kamino clone facility, brown gas cloud type city, Rebel Cruiser (which you retrace your steps through the entire ship), Kamino clone facility. My main complaint with the first Force Unleashed was that they revisited the same levels multiple times. They did the same thing again but the levels are longer and there is even less variety. The combat is fun and enjoyable, the story is forgettable and unlike the first game doesn't make sense in the Star Wars Universe.

To sum up my feelings:

Pros:
Decapitate Storm Troopers
Combat is enjoyable
Force lightening
Pacing
Authentic Star Wars feel, sounds art design etc

Cons:
Lack of level variety
Short
Stability (see below)

This game requires Windows 7 Compatibility Mode be enabled if your running Windows 8. Before I enabled it the game would hard crash (power off) my machine during the intro cut scene. After enabling Compatibility mode the game would only occasionally crash to the desktop. Luckily since the game saves often and is fairly short the disruption was minimal. If the game had been longer or if the save points had been further apart it would have been a very different experience.
