reviewText:
A boring rushed and unimaginative cash-in, rehashing elements from the first game instead of adding anything new.

The Good:
* Well Acted.
* Very Pretty effects, sound design, levels and set pieces.
* Combat starts off being fairly entertaining.

The Bad:
* Short (6 hours long)
* Boring Writing and story.
* One dimensional characters.
* Totally monotonous (backtracking and padded to the extreme.)
* Levels are re-used to pad the length as you go back through them in reverse.
* Major Boss fights go on *way* too long. They have *far* too much health.
* All Stormtroopers can be taken out with force lightning or force push.
* Everyone else can be taken out with grapple (which you'll use 100s of times)
* Fights with giant robots are interesting once or twice... you have to do the same fight 20-30 times though.

Only buy it if it's less than £5 and you love Star Wars.
Play it solely for the fact that it's Star Wars.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Great game, love the way it still works after so long. Its great with a controller, which is where one of my issues arises. I do not know if it is my controllers fault (doubt it, its the newest logitech one and i rarely used it before this game) but during the mission where you are on kamino jumping from platforms onto cloning tables, the sprint and jump buttons start glitching out. They also do on the ketboard. How conveneint. The way you fight is really cool, and on easy i have never died or gone below 70 percent health. That could be its too easy or that i have played this on multiple other platforms, so its cool to see the game on ps3, wii, ds. and pc. But this game lacks original map play. Every damn missions is the same ♥♥♥♥. jumping constantly, opening doors, and sprinting around. It feels like they made a small section of something, then cloned it a thousand times with a little bit of random and then theres your map. some levels are meant to make you super mad and i ended up removing the game because of it. Jumping on moving platforms while the controls glitch out for 30 minutes is boring as hell. Also the combat is way too easy. If you force lift a container and throw it ANYWHERE it automatically hits an enemy making the game super easy. Also you would think with 2 lightsabers you would cut enemies up realy fast. Nope. Just like assassins creed you are wacking and slashing for 20 seconds before someone dies. The game that adds realistic combat will be the game that wins all the cards. Its a fun game, for sure not worth 20 bucks. I got it along with many other in a humble bundle deal for 12 dollars which was a steal. If you like star wars youll like this. I cant reccomend it due to the horrible combat and terrible map designs.

reviewText:
I personally cant recommend this game for a few reasons. 1) its not a very fun game to play. not once did i think to my self this is engaging or entertaining i played it to get it off my hard drive and to see if its any good I can only tick one thing off the list there. the controls are boring and unintuitive the abhorrent use of F@&KING quick time events is infuriating and Its just lacking in every way. The graphics are bad even compared to games such as oh i don't know Republic commando that came out almost 10 years ago. its badly modeled, the voice acting is passable but not overly entertaining  or important to the story (i use the term story very loosely). The game is basically kill this room of enemy's fight a big enemy have a quick time event  rinse and repeat a few times  then fight a boss that is almost exactly the same as the new enemy of the level only bigger with a new weakness. there are 9 levels well that's a lie there are 5 levels but they split them up into 9 parts, why i don't really know as i didn't realize until i finished that id played 9 BLOODY LEVELS its short even for a short game. but that's possibly a good thing as it would be unbearably dull if it was any longer.

now for the goodish parts, its OK for a bundle game and It has boba fett in it for all of about 5 minutes of cut scene.
All in all its awful so awful in fact that i would rather buy the disc break it into lots of little bits and snort them as at least then it would cause me a short death compared to the laboriousness hell that this game has put me through so unless you like quick time events and a dull unengaged story then go ahead otherwise RUN FOR THE HILLS

reviewText:
To oversimplify it, the first one is better.
Generally I look at games in terms of Gameplay, plot, systems/stability ('under the hood' judged from outside) and graphics. Usually we like sequels to improve on most of these, but to get only one out of four is slightly disappointing.


Graphically: obvious improvements over the first one, pretty good. Generally consistent aesthetic to what I'd expect from Star Wars too. Not many really obvious graphical bugs or anything, a few things fade out of existence from now and then, but that's probably a functional thing so they don't fill your memory with pieces of broken box.

Stability-wise, it's a step down from the original. I completed that twice with two crashes (which I think only happened because I was alt-tabbing about). This seems to be crashing every 60-90 minutes on average. Not sure why, sometimes it's in heavy combat, and sometimes it happens when I was lurking at a checkpoint eating a bag of crisps and the game wasn't really doing anything.
My computer is definitely powerful enough to handle it. Maybe the backwards/forwards compatibility is causing problems.
But aside from occasionally crashing, the game seems fairly well built, technically at least. I've yet to run into any notable bugs.

Gameplay: the biggest disappointment.
I’ll preface this by saying I’m not very good at this kind of game, I prefer a nice FPS where I can lurk in the distance and shoot people in the head, or an RTS where I can turtle away in some forgotten corner of the map. That said the gameplay was at times boringly easy on its ‘normal’ difficulty, at worst it tended to be awkward.

The cut scenes are long and there's just a massive amount of time spent in quick time events. Would calling then ‘slow time events’ be childish? It generally feels like they wanted to make an animated film, but couldn't, so they let you press buttons from time to time and call it a game.
Okay, that's an exaggeration, but it annoys me a bit.
For example, one of the iconic bits of the first game is when you pull a star destroyer out the sky, you do this by force gripping it, and pulling it down. (You also have to make it face you, for no apparent reason, other than to make it hit you in the face when it lands, but drama.) In a similar sequence in this game you just sort of watch, and when it tells you to, you press a button a few times.

Repetition is a bit problem, near the start fighting some giant rancor-eating monster you have to repeat identical game sections several times. While you're doing this, there's someone constantly shouting at you, telling you to do something, you've already sone once. And they complain you haven't done it yet multiple times before the sequence can repeat.

I think in this game someone says something like 'A single Jedi can turn the tide of a war', and in the first one I could more or less believe that. In this game it's just odd. I guess it's technically true, given the number of enemies that perfectly resist any attempt to damage them, with anything but one specific power, so you'd need a jedi. But it's sometimes odd. Some enemies need to be hit with a radial force push, a normal straight one doesn't work, but a radial one staggers or outright kills them. Perhaps they are actually invincible, but terrified of circles?

Then there's a massive number of force powered people, Sith acolytes or something, that will block your force powers. Some of them have lightsabers and block most melee attacks, so you have to grapple them; annoying I guess, but made more so by the fact there only seems to be one grapple animation. It’s slow, and very specific, and when you’re facing a few of them at the same time it’s incredibly tedious watching the same animation again and again. The only way I’ve found to make it fun is to try and line up the grapples so they fall off things when the animation completes. (You can briefly use powers on them while they’re standing up too.)

Then there are the robots. Lots of identical robots, that must be killed in more or less the same way every time. Repetitive and irritating. The only difference I’ve found is which exact buttons is used in the lasts stage of the quick time event. Another animation would make this better, but whatever…

The game also seems to forget what sensible people like; random sections turn into platformers where you have to climb things or traverse spaces with a mediocre advanced movement system. Fortunately for most of these, when you inevitably fall off they send you back to the start rather than killing you, which could be worse. But, for example, on Kamino there are airborne robots that are levitating, as they do. But they’re all staying perfectly still for no apparent reason, sitting in just the right place to let you cross places that the people controlling them shouldn’t be wanting you to cross.

Plot: (small rant here, sorry) It's a bit odd to be honest. Largely the apparent motivations of Starkiller. For a  large part of the game he seems to have turned into a whiney idiot, totally obsessed with a girl he barely knows, jeopardising the rebel alliance, his own life etc. for no logical reason. Which isn't inherently, I understand love is a strong motivator for people, leading to irrational behaviour, except the barely know each other. After a few mildly suggestive conversations in the first game, and a kiss he's infatuated?
That irritation aside, the rest of the plot is weak. Interesting enough to keep me playing, but just barely.

Summary:
Worse than the first.
Gameplay is kind of fun, tearing apart little people, but there are lots of irrationally awkward big things.
It likes to crash, for me at least. I’ve yet to figure out why.
It's kinda pretty though.

reviewText:
The Force Unleashed 2 is so much better than the first game in every way.

The visuals and art direction for everything (characters, environment, effects) is leaps and bounds better than the first entry. The gameplay itself gets a significant upgrade. You get all your abilities from the start (though you can still upgrade them as you level up), but the levels are integrated with varied enemies and barricades that require you to mix up your tactics at all points in time.

The action is fast-paced, and the story feels very much at home in the Star Wars setting. While the first game, you would only really play for the story, this game lets you blow through hundreds of enemies in a short play session that makes you feel like the most powerful Force-user to ever exist in the Star Wars universe.

7/10 Good""

reviewText:
The game is quite different from the original as the game engine has been redone making the game speed faster and very similar in tone to the God of War series. The game is shorter, but more fun to play and not as frustrating as the original. Better job has also been done in porting, but still leaves a lot to be desired. It tries to follow the mediocre story of the original, and again fails to make much sense.
Overall I liked the action packed ride and feel it is not inferior to the original as both games offer something unique.

TL;DR: Jedi Knight meets God of War.

TIPS:
- Apply 60fps fix
- Play with gamepad
- Disconnect gamepad before pre-rendered videos if they hang. (You can also skip them after hang, and re-watch them later)

reviewText:
UI - Rubbish. The assets don't scale past 720p. You literally get blocky pixelated icons and images on higher resolutions.
Story - Rubbish and short.
Game Length - 5 hours.
Boss fights - Tedious. Not fun. Also, very few of them.
Voice Acting - Bad.
Writing/Dialog - Cheesy and bad.
Combat - Same as the prequel. Same combos, same powers. It's just the game is so short they expedite the powerup process by a huge margin. The only difference is you have 1 more lightsaber so the melee animations are different.

I really enjoyed the first one. It had decent pacing and good writing with good set piece moments. It sent you to a variety of locations. It was a pleasant surprise. SW:TFU 2 is the opposite of all those things. There is no equivalent moment of I'll use the force to send a Star Destroyer crashing into the planet". There is no wow-factor. There is literally nothing to be had here.

SW:TFU2 is literally a "Starship Troopers 2"-type sequence. A horrible sequel to a terrific first entry.

Do not buy this game
date: it is a waste of money; not even for $5. You don't need to know what hapened to Starkiller after TFU1 because this sequel does not and will not live up to any form of expectations."

reviewText: Well about this game, lets start with the pro's. Since the first Star Wars the Force Unleashed the combat has massively improved. Starkiller is not only wielding two lightsabers but his powers have majorly increased. For me this was a really good thing, beacause I always wanted to see what starkiller is cable off, and in this game you experience the force at its maximum. Another thing I liked was the upgraded graphics. For its time, SWTFU 2 looked amazing and it still does on PC. Finally, the gameplay was also updated with loads of new moves and a very impressive engine. Nevertheless, SWTFU 2 suffers from a lot of problems. Let's start with the story. The story from the first game was interesting, quite comlicated and offered us a lot of lore. In this game however, the story lacks charater, polish, and doesn't make sense at some moments. This is a big flaw for me, as I enjoy Star Wars games for their story, and SWTFU 2 fails to deliver this at a passable level. Then there is the lenght. I completed the Campaign in a mere 5 hours. 5 ♥♥♥♥ING HOURS. For 29,99 I expected more than pretty graphics and a few costumes. Another HUGE flaw was the easy as balls and forgetable boss battle with, you guessed it, Dark Pops. Overal does this game not what a sequel should do. The campaign is shorter, the story is duller and hard to follow and the price is too high. Lucasarts did a lot of work on the outside (graphics, moveset and engine) that they completly forgot the ambiance, the vibe and the overal experience. A Star Wars game should give the player a memorable experiece instead of a shiny, polygon physics demo. That's why I recommend that you play the first one, buy the ultimate sith edition, and let this one pass.\n\nStar Wars The Force Unleashed II Gets a 5,1 out of 10

reviewText:
Rating this game is really difficult. On the one hand this game makes really fun, on the other hand you always got to think how much better it could have been with a bit more time and money for the producers.

The greatest strength of the game is its gameplay. Cutting of body parts of the storm troopers and use the force to let them fly through the air let you feel like a true bad ♥♥♥ and a powerful Jedi. The Force abilities are nearly the same as in the first game, which is fine, because they were great, but this time starkiller got 2 lightsabers instead of one. There are several types of enemies and boss fights, which all need a little bit different approach.

The Story of the game is ok, but not nearly as good as the great story of the first game. You play as starkiller or one of his clones (This not truly revealed in the game, but I personally believe the evidence pro the clone theory is stronger) and need to escape from the empire and reconnect with your friends from the rebellion. The greatest weakness of the game is the length of the story. You can easily beat this game in around 4 to 5 hours. There are only 4 real missions and a ridiculously short dogobah trip, which only consists of one 5 minutes long cut-scene with master Yoda. This is really sad, because I think with 2 or 3 more missions this game would have felt much more completed.

At least there are 4 different difficulty settings und 2 possible endings, which gives you a bit of replay value and outside of the campaign there is a shortly entertaining challenge mode. In the Playstation and X-BOX Version there is also a DLC-Level on Endor, which is quite enjoyable as well.

The Music of the game is really great. Some of the most typical parts of the soundtrack of the classic star wars trilogy are part of this game and feel really fitting in every scene.

Pro: -Gameplay is really entertaining
- True Star Wars atmosphere
- Great Sound
Contra: - Length of the game
- Story is not as good as in the first game

Result: At the end I am in the strange position, that I can neither recommend nor disapprove this game. When I think about FU2 I always feel a bit sad, but when I play it (Beat it now 3 or 4 times), I truly enjoy this game every time despite its flaws and have a great time with it.

6/10

reviewText:
Abysmally short campaign with DLC locked away for PC users. Would still recommend to anyone if on sale, especially if you haven't played the first - combat is great and other saber-wielding force user enemies keep it interesting - there's a fair variety of enemies & powers. A little repetitive, with some of the bossfights being laughable, however the bulk of the game, due to the short length, didn't lose its appeal so much & I had fun with it up to the Vader fight at the end, in contrast to the 1st game, which I found outstayed its welcome somewhat. Not very replayable though, and skins are limited compared to the first game. Does have Boba Fett though.

The Dagobah level also turned out to be nothing more than walking towards the cave & picking up holocrons. It's still pretty visually stunning though, even if levels are more functional than organic. Cutscenes are also well made. The game is neither particularly polished nor too glitchy, but everything that should work does so pretty smoothly.

QTEs are simple and perhaps overused but do change button sequences, which is nice. I have great respect for Sam Witwer, the face & voice of Starkiller, however Starkiller's voice can be annoying and rather whiny. Nevertheless, performances are far from lacklustre. Sound design is great overall  - sabers are well done, and deflection of blaster bolts is oh so satisfying. There's little story here & while Starkiller's return as a clone is completely uncalled for, it's not unwelcome.

Apologies for longwindedness & lack of structure. The game has its flaws, but for a low price it's definitely worth a play. (I found it worked best for me with my Xbox 360 controller - precision from the mouse is not needed here)

7/10

reviewText:
I only recommend this game if it is on sale. I wouldn't pay full price for this game. While short, the story still manages to be interesting. The graphics are pretty, in all its aspects. As far as gameplay goes, its a hack-and-slash game; however having said that (and being a fan of the Devil May Cry series -Apart from the reboot-), it has its own tweeks and perks that make it a bit more unique that your run of the mill hack-and-slash genres. The voice acting is rather solid, nailing the old character's voices perfectly whilst using an intresting voice actor for the main protagonist. Its a shame that this game is short, as I wouldn't of mind paying full price if the story was a tad longer.

Gameplay 6/10
Sounds/OST 7/10
Story 4/10 (Could be longer)
Graphics 8/10
Overall verdict: 6.5/10

reviewText:
This is a hard one to recommend :s
I can tell you straight away it doesnt deserve all the crap reviews its been getting, and doesnt feature any of the insanely irritating back-tracking missions (lets reuse every environment in the game! bad idea) that the first one featured (well hardly any).
However its a shame to see all the potential this game has wasted by a dumbed-down saber/powers system (initially I was fooled into thinking they had completely removed any meaningful combo system, but yeh its still there; only its completely useless even on unleashed mode), and the same 2 enemies to run away from throughout the game. Theres more crazy and unnecessary gameplay altering features some of which are buggy (air assaults dont work, grabs work too well)
The story while cool and action packed, seems hollow and progresses too quickly. There arent any meaningful boss-fights, and those present involve using quick-time event button mashing to win. I still love this game tho :D:D

reviewText: So I just got done beating the game after several years of putting it off and in short the game is okay at best. The game is approximately 4 hours long so don't go into it expecting much. It feels more like a long expansion pack than a $20 game so spend at your own discretion. Have not seen the dark side ending to this one, but the light side was okay, won't spoil it but it didn't make a whole lot of sense so you'll need to use your imagination with that. Again, the game overall is decent and its still the same old Force Unleashed combat and gameplay, just with force powers that feel a bit more powerful and a little less content, but fun if you're a fan of the series looking for something different from the traditional AAA titles.

reviewText:
Terrible, terrible, terrible. The entire game is a repetitive slog, especially the combat. If they had cut out the filler, the game would've been a fun 30 minutes. It has its spectacular moments, but they are few and far between and don't make up for the repetitive and boring gameplay. It's not just repetitive, though, it's also clunky and buggy. I had several times where I failed jumps and lost several minutes of progress because of the strange movement engine - I would jump and they would perform the jump animation but not leave the ground, then I would fall to my death. I also had cutscenes just straight up freeze on me several times. The worst case was the cutscene that plays when you finish the game. It just froze. I had to watch the ending on youtube. Combat is made even worse with the inclusion of quick time event kills. The same canned animations play over and over again when you finish off some of the tougher robot enemies. It's cool the first time only.

Want an actually fun action game / brawler? Try Bayonetta, God of War, Dante's Inferno, or any of the many other games where they actually thought about the gameplay and fun and the experience of playing instead of just trying to make it a spectacle and cash in on the star wars IP. Want a good star wars game? Try republic commando (or, if you don't dislike RPGs, KOTOR and KOTOR 2).

Don't buy this game, and if you do play it for some unfortunate reason, play it on easy. The difficulty scaling is stupid and doesn't make the game more interesting, it just makes it more frustrating and tiresome.

reviewText:
I try to keep track of which games I own / have played / have finished. It took me a while to remember I'd even played Star Wars: The Force Unleashed II, never mind finished it. And that really sums up the game.

Compared to the original Force Unleashed, it's more fun to play, slicker, and has far fewer moments that pretend to be challenging but are actually just annoying (no Purge Troopers here!). But it's also more forgettable, shorter (and yet still repetitive), less rewarding to replay, and the story somehow manages to be tedious despite the short length of the game.

I wouldn't recommend this even if you liked The Force Unleashed. I did, for all its flaws. This sequel does get rid of some of those flaws, but what remains is a scant few hours of disposable and unnecessary cruft. If you need to buy every Star Wars game that exists, then maybe consider this a low priority. I don't hate it; I just don't feel much about it at all, on those rare occasions I remember it exists.

reviewText:
I personally cant recommend this game for a few reasons. 1) its not a very fun game to play. not once did i think to my self this is engaging or entertaining i played it to get it off my hard drive and to see if its any good I can only tick one thing off the list there. the controls are boring and unintuitive the abhorrent use of F@&KING quick time events is infuriating and Its just lacking in every way. The graphics are bad even compared to games such as oh i don't know Republic commando that came out almost 10 years ago. its badly modeled, the voice acting is passable but not overly entertaining  or important to the story (i use the term story very loosely). The game is basically kill this room of enemy's fight a big enemy have a quick time event  rinse and repeat a few times  then fight a boss that is almost exactly the same as the new enemy of the level only bigger with a new weakness. there are 9 levels well that's a lie there are 5 levels but they split them up into 9 parts, why i don't really know as i didn't realize until i finished that id played 9 BLOODY LEVELS its short even for a short game. but that's possibly a good thing as it would be unbearably dull if it was any longer.

now for the goodish parts, its OK for a bundle game and It has boba fett in it for all of about 5 minutes of cut scene.
All in all its awful so awful in fact that i would rather buy the disc break it into lots of little bits and snort them as at least then it would cause me a short death compared to the laboriousness hell that this game has put me through so unless you like quick time events and a dull unengaged story then go ahead otherwise RUN FOR THE HILLS

Can't comment on the gameplay itself due to technical issues.

Controls don't work. AT ALL. I'm stuck in the first tutorial with no control whatsoever. Only keyboard commands that work are ESC (and then things work fine in the menus) and ALT-F4. Absolutely abysymal porting job. Apparently there are workarounds (uninstall/disable any devices that could confuse the game) but this is hardly a solution and is really a hack to make such a poorly done port playable. Definitely not recommended.

Will update later once I get the controls sorted out and can actually play the game.

reviewText:
All in all took about 8 hours and was very disapointing compared to the first which was super fun! Tracking sucks, computer controls are more of mouse mashing, and there are only 2 boss fights and like 3 levels. The game is a huge let down compared to the first! Get the first because it has much more content and a lot more story too it. It is only worth a 5 dollar steam sale !!!! Boss fights are repetetive and took up the bulk of the game baisiclly lol!

Overall not alot of thought put into the game :(

BEST move shift+E beats all characters that you cant spam lightning at.

reviewText:
The only BAD things about this game is that the story is too short and the ending is controversial (play the game to find out why). The story in the first game was much better.

However there are alot of GOOD points to this game. The gameplay is much more fun than the first game. Graphics and sound are beautifully synchronized. Camera is not a pain. Boss fights are very interesting at not a hassle. Game mechanics are great. Fighting is awesome.

Overall get this game if you want 5-6 hours of fun slashing bad guys with lightsabers!

reviewText: The combat is fun for the first 10 minutes, then it becomes a repetitive task with no real challenge. Leveling is boring, and although the Force Powers are better than on the first one, there's no challenge at all, nor need to actually level them up.\nThe Story, if we can call it such, is stupid and boring. The game is short, which instead of coming as a shortcoming is actually a blessing, if I had to endure to two more hours of QTEs and Where is she?!" I don't think I could have kept going."

reviewText: WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥..... First loved the first game and completed it multiple times and when this came out i couldnt buy it a few years later i rememered it was out and bought it. I wish i has never bought this game even when it was on sale. The game has pretty much 3 big levels split up and really only and 8 hour campainge that all there is to this game. At the end there is no huge climax or awesome twist its is just like well congrats u win heres a ♥♥♥♥ cliff hanger and no real awesome event at the end like the last. In the end this game has such great potential and if they put the time and love in like they did to the first one then it could have lived up, but this isnt the case this game fell short and was just a huge money grab for the company and they never really cared about this game and accualy pleasing fan.
